cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £ 9 to Brindisi.
The combined sea and special train fare has been reduced to £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Mersailles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1905..

div.head:
THE TSAR AND PEACE.
HOPEFUL INTERVIEW.
ACTION OF ZEMSTVOS.
ULTIMATUM TO THE THRONE.

div.p: in an audience granted to the American Minister at Tsarkoe Selo the Tsar indicated his willingness to consider the subject of Feace. In his telegram the Minister describes this interview as being a most hopeful one.
(Reuter.)

The Congress of the Zemstvos was composed of 250 delegates. It adopted an emphatically worded address to the Tsar demanding the Convocation of a national assembly to be elected by universal suffrage, in order to decide the question of war or peace, and to abolish the vicious, dangerous, and ignorant bureaucracy.

It impresses on the Tsar his responsibility and warns him against any delay. A deputa tion has been appointed to present the address to the Tsar. This address is practically an ultimatum that the country sends to the Throne. The style is equally remarkable. The Tsar is addressed throughout as "you" and the word "Majesty" is entirely wanting. The conventional expressions of "loyalty" and "devo- tion" are also absent. (Reuter.)
The Congress of Zemstvos is to send a delegation to the Tsar with a demand for the convocation of the representatives of the people to decide on peace or war. (Havas)
Everybody here is astounded at the audacity of the Congress of the Zemstvos. (Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN WARSHIPS AT MANILA.
AMERICANS TAKE POSSESSION.
div.p: The Americans have taken possession of the Russian warships here. They will disarm and dismantle them. The crews will be liberated on parole.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
TSAR THANKS RODJESTVENSKY.
PROUD OF HIS COURAGE.
div.p: The Tsar has telegraphed to Admiral Rodjestvensky heartily thanking him, and saying that it was God's will rot to give success, but that the country is proud of his courage, and "God will console us all." (Reuter.)

div.head:
FRANCE'S FOREIGN POLICY.
A CHANGE OF FRONT.
div.p: The French newspapers intimste that as a part of the new policy a new Ambassador will go to Berlin and a new envoy to Morocco. As an evidence of the situation which the resignation of M. Delcassé modified, the French Minister of War conferred with the commanders of frontier Army Corps on Wednesday, and ordered them to bring their forces up to full strength. (Reuter.)

div.head:
SIGNIFICANT NAVAL MOVE.
SHIPS RECALLED FROM CHINA STATION.
div.p: The "Standard" learns that it is decided to recall all the battleships from the China station immediately. (Reuter.)

div.head:
NORWAY.
UNION FLAG HAULED DOWN.
div.p: The Union flag has been hauled down, and the Norwegian flag hoisted on Fort Akershus amidst rapturons enthusiasm and the salutes of artillery. 30,000 persons sang patriotic songs. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION.
div.p: Germany has sent a note to the Powers stating that it adheres to the demand of the Sultan of Morocco for the holding of an international conference. (Havas.

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Notts beat Oxford by 87 runs at Oxford.
Yorkshire beat Cambridge University by an innings and 43 runs.
(Reuter.

div.head: GOLF CHAMPIONSHIP.
div.p: Braid won the open Golf Championship at St. Andrew's.
(Reuter.)

div.head: EXECUTION.
div.p: Ibrahim Abdel Gayar will shortly be executed at Cairo for parricide at Yalache, Beliana, in 1904.

div.head: THE PLAGUE-
div.p: A new case of plague was admitted into hospital yesterday at Menouf. There are now four cases under treatment.

div.head: ZAGAZIG POST OFFICE.-
div.p: The Public Works Ministry has decided to construct a new post office at Zagazig at a cost of L.E. 6,000.

div.head: THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.
div.p: The "Ministere Public" has lodged an appeal against the judgment of acquittal given by the Assiout Court in the Ghirgeh scandal case.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.-
div.p: We are asked to remind our readers of the grand concert to be given to-morrow morning by the Bracale orchestra, composed of 50 executants.

div.head: THE TRIAL
div.p: of Constable Camilleri, the dismissed member of the Alexandria City Police force, will take place on Tuesday next at the British Consulate, Alexandria.

div.head: MARIOUT RAILWAY.-
div.p: An agreement has been arrived at between the Daïra Khassa and the Railway Administration in regard to goods traffic on the Mariout Railway.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: 7 vessels passed through the Canal on the 7th inst., of which 4 were British, 1 Egyptian, 1 German, 1 Dutch. The receipts for the day were frs. 180,514.54, making the total from 1st inst. frs. 1,792,015.50.

div.head: ASSOCIATED COTTON GINNERS.-
div.p: M. Escoffier, director of the Credit Lyonnais, and Mr. Critchley, director of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, have joined the board of the Associated Cotton Ginners.

div.head: ALHAMBRA.-
div.p: Santanello, which was successfully produced last night, will be given again to-night. To-morrow a matinée performance of Primavera Scapigliata will be given, and in the evening Santanello with La Gran Via.

div.head: CHANGES AT PORT SAID.-
div.p: The site of the new station at Port Said will be on the north-east corner of Lake Menzaleh, which is rapidly being filled up for that purpose. The Custom-house will be removed to the site of the present station.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Waily district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at daylight on Monday, and in the Abdeen district during Monday night and at daylight on Tuesday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS.
div.p: From the 1st Jan. to 8th June, 383,324 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 215,516 tons, Newcastle 73,151, Scotland 55,691, Yorkshire 23,273, and other districts 15,243 tons. Last year the quantity received during the corresponding period was 432,022 tons.

div.head: NEW PUMPING INSTALLATION.-
div.p: The improve- Iments to be made in the pumps at Ghizeh and Ghezireh are estimated to cost L.B. 12,670. Of the credit voted for that purpose L.E. 188 has been paid. The total of the separate credit voted for the installation of the pumping machinery in East Ghizeh is L.E. 20,000.

div.head: YELLOW SLAVE TRAFFIC.-
div.p: A young Japanese girl, 16 years of age, has complained to the Alexandria Gouvernorat of the character of the woman, a Russian Jewess, who has brought her from Hong Kong to Alexandria on the pretence of employing her as a maid. An enquiry has been opened into the case. The girl has been taken to the British Consulate.

div.head: BEAU-RIVAGE SMALL DANCE.
div.p: The small dance at the Beau-Rivage Hotel on Thursday next promises to be a most attractive function. The band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment will perform during dinner and will also furnish the music for the dance. Tables for dinner that evening should be ordered in advance. No invitations will be issued, as all will be welcome.

div.head: DESTRUCTION OF CROPS.
div.p: The lawlessness in the villages does not appear to be on the decrease. Cases of destruction of crops are becoming very frequent, and result often from most trivial causes. For example, while Farag Youssef, of Ezbet Sidham Abdob, Minet-el-Kamh district, was celebrating his marriage on Thursday evening, some persons belonging to the same ezbeh destroyed his cotton crops merely because he did not invite them to the wedding. On Wednesday night a great field of corn in the Tonkh district, said to be 50 feddans in extent, was destroyed by fire. The owner believes that it was a case of incendiar ism due to a vendetta.

div.head: A RED SEA SHARK.-
div.p: The Ports and Light houses Administration's lighthouse tender "Aida" has returned to Alexandria after three weeks' inspection in the Red Sea. Very fine weather was met with during the whole of the trip with the exception of a stiff northerly breeze between Ashrafi and Suez. The only interesting experience met with was when one of the biggest sharks ever seen or read about in piscatorial annals was reen. It was basking in the sun near the surface close to Shadwan lighthouse and was certified to be between 25 and 30 feet in length, with a breadth across the nose of 5 feet, being of the shovel-nose species. Lots of barnacles were observed all over its body. Sharks of 17 feet in the tropics are considered extraordinarily big, but such an enormous shark is almost unknown,

div.head:
THE COTTON WORM.
LITTLE DAMAGE ANTICIPATED.
div.p: Mr. Mac' ell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, returned to Cairo from Alexandria last night.

Mr. Machell, who has been making a visit of inspection in the Behera province, examined for himself the work which is being done towards the destruction of the cotton worm, and found that in the northern part of the province, where the cotton crops are much later than in other parts, very little damage has been done. He also found that great interest was being taken in the work by the native population, that every precaution was being exercised, and that the instructions of the inspectors of the Ministry of the Interior were being faithfully carried out.
Mr. Machell anticipates that great good will result from the steps which are being taken for the destruction of this pest, and that the crop will not suffer to any very great extent.

div.head: SIWA OASIS.
div.p: Mahmoud Bey Rasmi, who was sent on an special mission to the Siwa Oasis to examine into certain differences' which had arisen between the mam ur and a number of the inhabitants, has returned to Cairo, and reports that all the differences have been amicably settled to the satisfaction of every party.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF THE SIRDAR.
div.p: Sir F. R. Wingate Pasha left Cairo yesterday evening by the 6.35 p.m. train. A considerable crowd assembled at the station to witness the departure of his Excellency, who was accompanied by five officers of the Egyp tian Army. Two compartments were reserved for the party and also special seats in the dining-car of the International Sleeping and Restaurant Car Company.
The Sirdar embarks for Europe this afternoon on the Austrian Lloyd steamer.

div.head: AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC AGENCY.
div.p: The Hon. J. W. Riddle, American Diplo matic Agent in Egypt, who has been transferred to Roumania in a similar capacity, left for Odessa yesterday on his way to take up his new pest. He will be replaced at Cairo by Mr. Idding, formerly attached to the American Embassy at Rome.

div.head: ST. MARK'S CHURCH.
div.p: The following are the services for Whitsun Day (June 11):-
8 a.m. Holy Communion.
11 a.m. Matins and Sermon. Te Deum and Jubilate (B. Tours). Anthem "Drive far from us the mortal foe," by Vincent Novello. Noon. Choral celebration of Holy Communion. (Woodward in E flat).
6.15 p.m. Evensong and sermon. Anthem, "Come, Holy Ghost," by Thomas Attwood. Magnificat and Nunc Dimittis (B. Tours).

div.head: SERIOUS STREET COLLISION.
div.p: A serious, collision occurred in Cairo on Thursday between a tram and a cab. The cab, which was occupied by Tewfik Bey Seoudi, a Cairo barrister, was proceeding along the street leading from the Esbekieh to Clot Bey-street and was just turning the corner when it was overtaken by a tram going in the same direction. The driver of the cab shouted loudly to the tramdriver, but the latter appar rently lost his head, for he continued on his way without slackening speed. The force of the collision was considerable and one horse was killed on the spot whilst the other was severely injured. Tewfik Bey Seoudi was thrown from the carriage and was badly bruised and much shaken, but the coachman succeeded in leaping from his seat and escaped injury.
Both the driver of the cab and of the tram were taken to Ataba el-Khadra caracol for an enquiry to be instituted.

div.head: "SOIREES NOIRES."
div.p: We have on more than one occasion expressed our disapproval of the "soirées noires" by means of which the management of the Théatre des Nouveautés in Cairo endeavours to attract large audiences, and we consider it to be our duty to once more protest against such performances being allowed. The short play which was produced on the stage of the "Nouveautés, at a recent entertainment of this description, was illustrative of the depths to which some artistes can degrade themselves by publicly portraying characters which are repulsive to all right-thinking persons, and it is very regrettable that an audience can be found to lend their support to the presentation of such exhibitions. We have no desire to appear straight-laced or narrow-minded, but we will risk this charge being laid against us, and we feel assured that the great majority of our readers will agree with us in our emphatic protest. We trust that any future announcement of the holding of a soirée noire" by this or any other theatre or music-ball, will cause the Government and consular authorities to intervene and put a stop to it.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The P. & O. S.S. "Osiris" left drydock this morning and sailed for Port Said.
The Papayanni S.S. "City of Oxford" arrived at Liverpool last night.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF GENERAL GALLIENI.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.8. "Melbourne" arrived yesterday from Madagascar and Manritius, having on board, in addition to 150. military passengers, General Gallieni, the Governor-General of Madagascar. This officer is now retiring from the service, having spent the last six years in the colony without having once been to France on leave in that time. The vessel left at 10 p.m.

div.head: RUSSIAN REFUGEES.
div.p: The Harris and Dixon Line 8.S. "Carnley" has just sailed. She is on her way to Odessa from Shanghai, at which port she embarked 955 Russian refugees.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA-TRIESTE LINE.
div.p: I am informed that the Alexandria-Trieste line of the Austrian Lloyd Company is to be doabled, and that, with this end in view, three passenger ships with a maximum speed of 20 knots are to be built so as to enable the company to run two vessels a week each way.

div.head: EXPORT OF SALT.
div.p: The Port Said Salt Association appears to have been considerably busier of late than usual. Their export of salt this year for the East has not been abnormally large, but to-day they have two large ships loading, the "Ardito," which is to take 1,000 tons, and the "Alton," a full cargo for Penang, to which port most of their cargoes are consigned. They appear to have. relinquished their old method of raising the cargoes in ton tubs in favor of hand labour, which is undoubtedly the more expeditious..

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lieutenant-Colonel T. R. Lucas, C.B., the Senior Medical Officer at Alexandria, is under orders to leave Egypt for England to take over the command of the depot and training school of the Royal Army Medical Corps at Aldershot. This is a very important billet, and the appointment is fully justified by the high reputation Colonel Lucas has obtained as one of the most able officers of the R.A.M.C. All young officers on joining the R.A.M.C. are attached to this Aldershot establishment and all the men of the Corps are sent there for training. It is one of the biggest depots in the service, and its command is considered one of the most important appointments that can be bestowed on a member of the R.A.M.C.

Lieut.-Colonel Lucas, M.B., C.B., was born in 1858 and entered the army in 1881. He obtained his C.B. in 1900 and was promoted lieut.-colonel in the following year. The following is the record of his services:-served Egypt, 1882 (despatches, medal with clasp, Khedive's star); Sudan expedition, 1884 (despatches twice, two clasps); Nile Expedition 1884-85 (two clasps); Sudan Frontier Field Force, 1885-86; Burmah, 1892-93 (despatches); South Africa. We heartily congratulate Colonel Lucas on his new appointment, which shows the great confidence placed in his professional abilities by the home authorities, for it is one of the most responsible positions in the R.A.M.C.

Mr. Felice, H. M.'s Vice-Consul at Zagazig, is going on leave and will come to Alexandria about the middle of this month. We regret to say that the health of the estimable: representative of Great Britain at Zagazig still leaves much to be desired. The many friends of Mr. Felice in Egypt hope that his holiday will do him good.
The Rev. R. Wormell, M.A., of Alexandria, has left for England on a six weeks' holiday.
Mr. F. H. Manley, Agent for Lloyd's and Reuter's at Alexandria, leaves for Burope to day on three months' leave.
The Shah of Persia has conferred the Order of the Lion and Sun on M. Ninoi, commercial director of the Sucreries Company at Alexandria. M. Ninci returns to Alexandria to-morrow from Italy.
The funeral of the late Mr. E. C. Manuk

took place yesterday and was largely attended. The funeral cortège left deceased's house at 5 p.m. for St. Catherine's Cathedral, whence, after the funeral service, it proceeded to the Roman Catholic Cemetery. The pall-bearers were Messrs. Michel Sinadino, Ambroise Ralli, Clement Suares, Roberto Giglio, John Haicalis, and Petrachi.

The following relations and friends of the late Mr. Manuk have contributed donations to the Religieuses Gardes Malades de Notre Dame, viz, Mrs. Hector Gantes, £1; Mr. and Mrs. Mario Vells, £1; Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Vella, £1; Mr. and Mrs. Jules Gantes, £1; Mr. Edward Gantes, £1; Mrs. Ed. J. Manuk, £2; Mr. and Mrs. D. G. Paleologos, £1. The Sister Superior of this association takes this opportunity of thanking the donors for their gifts. The late Mr. Manuk was nursed during his illness by one of the Sisters of this excellent Alexandria nursing home.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expremed by our correspondenta, bus we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limita-free

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, I read the ontspoken criticism on the Egyptian Development Syndicate, which you have reproduced from the "Morning Post" to day, with great interest. Why has there not been more criticism of similar companies, which, unfortunately for their misguided supporters among the public, are not in an embryonic state but have been successfully floated 1 It is surely a matter in which the Egyptian Government should interfere. The stipulations which the Government laid down in the case of mining companies have been of some service in preventing wild speculation in the Egyptian mining market. Cannot the Government also lay down conditions which will prevent the indiscriminate launching of such companies, many of which are only formed for the benefit of the promoters, and to get money from the credulous Egyptian investor, whose speculative instincts invariably overbalance his reasoning capacities? But it is probably asking too much for the Government to interfere, as company promoting appears to be the goal of every Anglo-Egyptian official on leaving the service of the Government. It would be interesting to know who the gentleman is, whose services have been secured by the Egyptian Development Syndi- cate, but whose name is so carefully withheld from publicity. We are told that this gentleman has acquired a thorough knowledge of the requirements of this country during a residence of 25 years. I wonder if he is some ex-Anglo-Egyptian official.-Truly yours,
"INVESTOR."
Alexandria, June 9.

In regard to our correspondent's demand for the interference of the Egyptian Government, we may point out that he fails to distinguish between Egyptian companies and companies formed to do business in Egypt but incorporated abroad, which are wholly independent of any Egyptian authorisation or control. As to the former category it would be apposite to quote Lord Cromer's words from his Report published in 1900 (Egypt No. 1 [1900] p. 32):-

..In the second place, I wish to repeat the warning I gave last year, to the effect that, when it is stated that the formation of an Egyptian company has been sanctioned by the Egyptian Government, this only means that the company has conformed to certain conditions laid down by the Government as an essential preliminary to the sanction being given. It does not mean more than this. It does not in any way signify that the Government either approves or disapproves of the special enterprise with which the company is concerned, considered on its own merits. In saying this, I have no wish whatever to discourage native investors. Some projects laid before them will, without doubt, be based on thoroughly sound principles, and will be likely to prove remunerative, others, again, may be of a more doubtful and speculative character. The Government does not undertake to distinguish between these two categories of investments. Its functions are strictly limited to laying down certain conditions, which the experience of other countries has shown to be of a nature calcnlated to protect the interest of investors. The latter have then to decide for themselves, and I should add that the experience of other countries has also shown that no legislative or administrative measures can adequately protect the careless investor. Egyptians, therefore, will do well not to go to the one extreme of exaggerated mistrast of all projects which may be laid before them, or to the other extreme of accepting too hastily the accuracy of any facts and opinions which may be embodied in a prospectus, but to adopt the middle course, which consists in carefully examining for themselves, with the aid of competent friends, the merits of each special proposal, whether it be put forward by Europeans or by their own countrymen.".

div.head:
LOTTERIES IN EGYPT.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,-In common with many other Anglo- Egyptians I have up till lately been accustomed to buy now and again in the streets of Cairo a few lottery tickets. I have never gained anything, but feel sufficiently rewarded by the sense of pleasurable expectation which my purchases have afforded me, and have always looked forward with a certain amount of mild excitement to the reading of the winning numbers in the local newspapers. The Egyptian Government has in its wisdom decided that lotteries are immoral and that, as they had been abolished for nearly a century in England, Egypt should also follow in the wake of progress and declare lotteries to be an abomination. Accordingly, we saw the usual machinery put into motion and a short time ago we were given to understand that lotteries were things of the past. The result was that a large number of poor people, who had been accustomed to hawk lottery tickets about the streets, were deprived of their means of subsistence, and some of them who were Jews made a manifestation at the house of Mr. Cattani here. If the English officials, who do guide the destinies, and try also to guide the morals of this country, had been consistent in this matter, there would have been nothing more to say. No doubt lotteries, like many other things in Egypt, are reprehensible and ought to be suppressed. Moreover, to judge from your columns, moral faddists and cranks of every description appear to be increasing in Egypt in these latter days, and their opinions as to the regeneration of Egypt must be attended to. I should be the last to criticise this step but for the inconsistency that has been displayed. For a few weeks the new law against lotteries appeared to be stringently enforced and the sale of the tickets ceased in the streets. But Low the vendors of these tickets have appeared again, and on enquiry I find that the lottery tickets of some benevolent societies are allowed to be sold. The Government has prohibited lotteries and the sale of tickets in public places, because obviously lotteries are injurious to public morality. But it makes an exception in the case of benevolent societies, whose lotteries it authorises! Could anything be more inconsistent ? If lotteries are bad per se, are they a whit less bad if organised by these societies! We may argue then, that although gambling hells and disorderly houses are bad and ought to be suppressed, yet, if run by benevolent societies to enrich their coffers, they can be tolerated as legitimate! There is no disputing the appositeness of the parallel. Why such an exception was allowed I fail to discover, for it is based on that most specious but immoral principle that evil should be permitted if good can come out of it. Who is responsible? The general rule now is to shift responsibility for every abuse in Egypt on to the Capitulations, but I cannot see where the Capitulations come in here, so the prevalent principle of official irresponsibility, "When in doubt, abuse the Capitulations," does not hold good in this case. It would be interesting to discover who was responsible for this exception, which the flimsiest casuistry cannot justify. I am, etc.,

div.head:
EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND.
AN ERRATUM.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,-My letter in your issue of April 1 causes the Bishop of Pennsylvania to remark of the overturn of the American branch of the Egypt Exploration Fund, that "the action of the London Committee is amusing." Allow me now to quote his entire letter to me: "My dear Dr. Winslow: I have read your pamphlet, The Truth about the Egypt Exploration Fund,' with deep, and painful interest. It has the charm of a well-told detective story, but its revelations of ambition and. deceitfulness on the part of others with whom you were associated, are painful. The action of the London Committee is amazing. The Fand owes far more to you than to ary one else who has been connected with it, and I feel sure that if all the facts could be put before a full meeting of the Committee, there would be a reconsideration of the unjust action affecting your relationship to the organisa tion. I wish I could hope for a reconsideration of the action of some persons in Boston, but I fear they will find no place for repentance. "I shall certainly not renew my subscription to the Fund so long as the present organisation of the American Branch remains unchanged.-Faithfully yours.,
O. W. WHITAKER."

The London Committee should try to atone for "the enormous blunder" by reparation of some kind to the 600 or 700 American subscribers, to the corps of 80 local secretaires, and to myself as their head official. Thus, with confidence restored, there would be strong hope for a renewal of large financial support.- Yours faithfully,

div.head: BOOKS ON RUSSIA.
div.p: Amidst the masses of books dealing with Russia which are now being issued by the English publishing houses none are more instructive than "Russia as it really is," by Mr. Carl Joubert, and "Russia in Revolution," by Mr. G. H. Perris. Both these works are issued in Bell's Indian and Colonial Library. They are well printed and bound and are remarkably cheap. They give a vivid idea of Russia at the present day and are well worth reading by all who take an interest in the greatest national crisis since the outbreak of the French Revolution.

By the fall of a straw stack on a Suffolk farm a hen was buried. To the great surprise of the men engaged in carting away the straw the bird was found alive, sitting on an egg, after twenty-seven days' imprisonment.

div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.

div.head: TRADE IN THE SUDAN
NEW ROUTES TO ABYSSINIS
div.p: It is interesting to observe the various li stages in the colonisation of a country like the Sudan. Two very interesting accounts of the zeul and enterprise showa in opening up trade and trade routes to Abyssinia bure just come to hand. One is that of Captain Wilson, until recently the Inspector of Kodok Province ; the other is that of Mr. Jesser, an agent of the wealthy American, Mr. Mar. millan, who takes a great interest in explor ing on the Sudan frontier

Captain Wilson's object was to increase the trade with Soathern Abyssinia by the waterways of the White Nile and Sobat Rivers. Menelik had given the Sudan Govern. ment a trading station at Etang, on the Baro River, but, for some reason or other, this had been a failure, and Captain Wilson's inain idea was to find out the reasons for this, and, if possible, remove the obstacles. Together with the representatives of the leading trading houses at Khartoum, Captain Wilson arrived at Etang and almost immediately found the causes of lack of trade. The station w39 unsuitable and not on the trade road. The Egyptian merchants bad not chosen quite the merchandise required, and asked exorbitant prices, and the chief men of the district had put every obstacle in the way of trade. Besides this there had been fighting amongst themselves. It was found that the object of the traders was not to gain and establish regalar trade, but to make as much as they could in one swoop before the natives could find out the true value, and then to retire with the cash. One agent openly declared that he withdrew his goods because he could not make 100 per cent. profit, expecting that the Abyssinians were like the negro tribes, the Dinkas and the Shillaks, who were at first porsuaded to part with their goods for a few beads.

Captain Wilson at once proceeded to look out for a new station, and steamed ap the Baro to the place where it is joined by the River Jaijebbs, and fixed on a site for a market at Finkio, a village which is above high-water mark, free from swamps, and on the trade road between Abyssinis and the country of the Anyoks. He then determined to visit all the "babe," or trade doors, in the district, and find out why they were closed. Saio was the first place visited, and the nephew of the headman Jots, as is the custom, showed the party every hospitality. He insisted on the dismissal of the negro carriers, as he had strict orders to see that the goods were carried by his own men. The boa iman Takallin was evidently afraid of trading, and complained of the prices of the Egyptian traders. For some reason or other he bad closed the door to trade, and very reluctantly admitted that he had received orders from his chief, Rss Tesemma, ordering him to open the road.

The next place visited was Gore, the city of Ras Tesemma. The Ras was away at Addis Abeba, it was said, building a house for himself at the capital, but his representative expressed bimself pleased with the choice of the new trading station. One of the days of the visit being market day, a proclamation was made to the people, telling them that trade was to be encouraged, and that the door was open. One of the merchants with Captain Wilson exposed his goods for sale, and in a very short time disposed of the whole lot to the value of £50. Contracts were made for coffee and bees'-wax on the spot, and there is no doubt the chances of trade are excellent, and supply and demand heavy for fair exchange. During the stay of the expedition & party of merchants arrived from 28 far off as Massowah t) trade in coffee and ! boes' wax. Şurely if it is worth their while to koop op al trade from such a distance, the merchants from Khartoum, with ever ought to be successful in competing with them.

There is little doubt that Captain Wilson's timely visit has had the desired effect. The merchants are now busy collecting the kind of merchandise needed for exchange, and the Abyssinians are very quick to dispose of their prodace if only the doors are kept open. There is a great demand in those parts for swords, not less than 3ft. lin. curved or straight, without handles, as the natives prefer putting on their own hilts. Evidently a good many of these are made in England ; one examined closely was marked "Manufacture Garanti, London." Baamelled iron drinking-cops, 4) ins. high, blue or white, would find a ready sale, as would enamelled iron teapots of the cheapest quality. All these swords, cups and teapots ought to be stamped with Monelik's crest. The chiet produce of this part of Abyssinia is coffee and bees'-wax and a certain amount of ivory, but as the tribute of the local chiefs is paid in that article, and monopolized by them, very little trade can be done in that line. The whole district is a great grain-grow ing region, and has great possibilities for trad. if the roads are kept open. In his report Captain Wilson was able to say: "The roads are now fally open to trade and all obstacle removed."

The main object of Mr. Jesren's expeditio was to find a roata for trade with Abys. ginis having an outlet on the White Nile. Starting from Melat, & lace about 30 milonorth of Kodok (Pasbord.). Mr. Jessen's parts struck inland on March 9th, and marched or the north bank of Kor Adar. In high Nile thix stream flows fall into the main river, but in the dry senson, except for pools here and there, the bed is dry. Mr. Jessen traced the bed of the Kbor until he came to swampy ground, and by the vegetation and trees along the banks as far as his eye could trace it thr Khor tan ronth and then due enst. In the pools were hundreds of hippe, with sufficien! water to cover only • few, and game of al porta drinking at the pools. During the raius womon there must be & deep and strong por:
